Translated by Zhi Qian, a layman from the state of Yuezhi in Wu
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda and the Bodhisattvas: The people in the world, whether good men or good women,
who wish to be reborn in AmitÄyus's land, are divided into three groups, whose merits vary in size, and are not mutually inclusive.
The Buddha said:
What are the three groups?
The highest first group consists of those who leave home, abandon wives and children, cut off desires, become monks, pursue the Way of Non-action, become Bodhisattvas, and practice the six pÄramitÄs.
As monks, they do not violate the precepts, have a compassionate mind, diligently practice, should not be angry, and should not have sexual relations with women.
They observe the precepts purely, have no desires in their minds, sincerely wish to be reborn in AmitÄyus's land, and constantly think of it with utmost sincerity without interruption.
That person, when seeking the Way in this world, will naturally see AmitÄbha Buddha, bodhisattvas, and arhats in their dreams while lying down.

When that person's life is about to end, AmitÄbha Buddha will himself come flying with the bodhisattvas and arhats to welcome them, and they will be reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land, transformed and born in a lotus flower in the pond of the seven treasures.
They will naturally receive a long life and become a bodhisattva who has attained the stage of nonretrogression.
They will then fly together with the bodhisattvas to make offerings to the innumerable buddhas of the eight directions and above and below.
They will attain wisdom and courage, enjoy listening to the scriptures, and their minds will be joyful.
The seven-jeweled houses they live in will be in the sky, as they wish.
They will be close to AmitÄbha Buddha, wherever they wish to be. The Buddha said:

Those who wish to be reborn in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land should diligently uphold the scriptures and precepts, and practice the above teachings. Those who do so will be reborn in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land and will be respected by the assembly.
This is the highest first class.
The Buddha said:
As for those of the middle class, although they wish to be reborn in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land and are unable to leave home, abandon wife and children, sever desires, and become monks,

they should uphold the scriptures and precepts without transgression, and increase their giving and generosity. They should always believe and accept the Buddha's teachings deeply, and be sincere and faithful;
feed monks, build Buddha temples and stupas, scatter flowers, burn incense, light lamps, and hang various silks and satins;
in these practices, there is nothing to be rejected.
One should not be angry, but observe the precepts purely, have a compassionate mind, diligently cultivate, and cut off thoughts of desire.
Those who wish to be reborn in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land, without interruption for one day and one night.
That person will then, in this very life, also see AmitÃ¢bha Buddha in their dreams while lying down.
When the lifespan of that person is about to end, AmitÃ¢bha Buddha will transform, causing that person to personally see AmitÃ¢bha Buddha and his land.
Those who go to AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land can attain wisdom and courage.
The Buddha said:

If that person practices giving in this way, but then later regrets it, has doubts in their heart, does not believe in giving and making various kinds of merit leading to blessings in the next life, does not believe in the existence of AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land, and does not believe in being reborn in that land,
even so, if that person continues to think about it without interruption, temporarily believing and temporarily not believing, with a wavering mind and no fixed basis,
because they continue their good wishes as the basis, they will still be reborn there.
When the person's life is about to end due to illness, AmitÄbha Buddha will then transform himself into an image and let the person see it with their own eyes.
They will no longer be able to speak, but will joyfully and exuberantly think in their minds:
'I regret not knowing to observe the precepts and do good deeds. I will now be reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land.'
The person will then repent their past misdeeds, but their repentance will be of little avail and will not be able to save them.
When the person's life is completely over, they will be reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land.

They will not be able to reach AmitÄbha Buddha, but on the way they will see the natural seven-jeweled city on the outskirts of AmitÄbha Buddha's land, and their mind will be greatly delighted. They will then stay in that city.
They will be reborn in a seven-jeweled pond through transformation, and their body will naturally grow to full size.
In the city, they will stay there for five hundred years, and the city is two thousand li wide and long.
In the city, there are also houses made of the seven treasures, with seven-treasure bathing pools inside and outside.
In the bathing pools, there are also naturally fragrant flowers, and above the bathing pools, there are also rows of trees made of the seven treasures;
They all also produce the five tones.
When they wish to eat, there is naturally food in front of them, with a hundred flavors of food and drink;
Whatever they wish to obtain, it all arrives as they wish.
The people in the city are also happy, and the things in the city are like the natural things in the second heaven of the thirty-three celestials.
However, the people in the city cannot leave, and they cannot see AmitÃ¢bha Buddha, but only see his radiance, and their minds are filled with regret and joy.
They also cannot hear the sutras;
They also cannot see the assembly of bhiká¹£us;
They also cannot see the appearances of the bodhisattvas and arhats in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land.
The person's suffering is like this, but it is only a small punishment.
The Buddha also does not make one's body do anything. What is done naturally is obtained. All the mind itself turns towards the path and enters the city.
When that person originally sought the path in past lives, their mind and mouth were different, their words and thoughts were insincere, and they doubted the Buddha's teachings;
They also did not believe in it, and they will naturally enter the evil paths.
The Buddha AmitÃ¢bha has compassion and uses his spiritual power to lead them away from that.
In the city, the person will be able to leave after five hundred years.
They will go to where the Buddha AmitÃ¢bha is and hear the sutra, but their mind will not be enlightened;
They will also not be able to be among the bodhisattvas, arhats, and bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha to listen to the sutra.
The dwelling place they leave behind on the ground will not be able to make the dwelling follow their wishes to be lofty and large in the sky.
They will also be very far from the Buddha AmitÃ¢bha and will not be able to get close to the Buddha AmitÃ¢bha.
That person's wisdom is not clear, and they know few scriptures, so their mind is not joyful, and their intention is not enlightened.

After a long time, that person will also naturally have their wisdom enlightened and understand the scriptures, be bright, vigorous, and courageous, and their mind will be joyful, and they will then be like the first group above.
Why is this?

It is because that person, in their past lives when seeking the Way, did not uphold the precepts to a great extent, violated the Dharma of the scriptures, had doubts in their mind, did not believe the Buddha's words, did not believe that the Buddha's scriptures are profound, and did not believe in giving alms and doing good deeds, thinking that they will not receive blessings in the next life;
And because of their middling repentance, they do not believe in being reborn in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land, and their virtues are not sincere, for these reasons it is so.
This is the second middling group.
The Buddha said:

As for the three groups, those who wish to be reborn in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land, if they have nothing to give in charity, and are also unable to burn incense, scatter flowers, light lamps, hang various silks and satins, build temples and pagodas, and offer food to the Å›ramaá¹‡as,
they should cut off desires and have nothing to covet, attain the sÅ«tra quickly, be kind-hearted and diligent, not be angry, and observe the precepts purely, in accordance with the Dharma.
They should single-mindedly think of being reborn in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land, without interruption day and night for ten days.
When their life ends, they will immediately be reborn in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land, and will attain respect and wisdom and courage.
The Buddha said:
If those people, after doing this, then repent in the middle, have doubts in their mind, and do not believe that doing good will bring blessings in the next life;
and do not believe in being reborn in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land,
even so, they will continue to be reborn there.
When the lifespan of that person is about to end due to illness, AmitÄbha Buddha will cause that person to see the land of AmitÄbha Buddha in their dream while lying in bed.
The mind will greatly rejoice, and they will think to themselves:
I regret not knowing to do more good deeds. Now I will be reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land.
The person will only think this, unable to speak again. They will immediately repent their past mistakes, but the repentance will be of little use and will not be able to reach everywhere.
When that person's life ends, they will be reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land.
If they are unable to reach there, they will see a city of the seven treasures two thousand li away on the road. The mind will rejoice alone, and they will stay there.
They will also be reborn in a lotus flower in a pond of the seven treasures, and will naturally attain a large body.
That city will also be like the previous city, like the natural objects in the second TrÄyastriá¹ƒÅ›a Heaven.
That person will also stay in the city for five hundred years before leaving.
They will arrive at AmitÄbha Buddha's place, and their minds will be greatly delighted.
If a person listens to the sÅ«tra but does not understand it in their heart, is not joyful, and lacks wisdom, and knows the sÅ«tra to be insufficient,
The house they live in is on the ground, and they cannot make the house rise high in the sky as they wish.
They are also far away from AmitÄbha Buddha, unable to get close to him. It is the same for the second group of people with doubts.
After a long time, they will also have their wisdom open up and understand, know the sÅ«tra to be courageous, and their minds will be joyful, next to the first group.
Why is it so?

It is because in their past lives when seeking the Way, they had regrets and doubts, temporarily believing and temporarily not believing, not believing that doing good will bring blessings and virtues, and they all naturally obtained them.
According to their merits, whether they are inclined or not, each naturally turns towards the sutras and the path of practice, surpassing millions and myriads, without being able to reach it.
The Buddha said:
Those who wish to cultivate the bodhisattva path and be born in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land, after that, will all attain the stage of nonretrogression as a bodhisattva.
Those at the stage of nonretrogression as a bodhisattva will all have the thirty-two marks, purple-gold color, and eighty minor characteristics, and will all become buddhas.
Following their wishes, wherever they wish to become buddhas in other buddha lands, they will never again fall into the hells, animal realms, or hungry ghost realms.
According to their diligence in seeking the path, the timing of early and late is the same.
If one seeks the path without rest, one will surely attain it and not lose what one wishes for.
The Buddha told the bodhisattvas such as Ajita:

All heavenly beings, emperors, and people, I tell you all, those who wish to be reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land, although unable to make great progress, meditate, and uphold the scriptures and precepts, they should do good deeds:
First, do not kill living beings.
Second, do not steal.
Third, do not engage in sexual misconduct or have illicit affairs with others' spouses.
Fourth, do not deceive.
Fifth, do not drink alcohol.
Sixth, do not gossip.
Seventh, do not speak harshly.
Eighth, do not lie.
Ninth, do not be jealous.
Tenth, do not be greedy or stingy in the heart, do not be angry, do not be foolish, do not indulge in desires.
Do not regret in the heart, do not be skeptical.
One should be filial and obedient, be sincere and faithful, and believe deeply in the Buddha's teachings and words. One should believe in doing good and receiving its blessings in the next life.
If one upholds this and does not violate the Dharma, whatever one wishes in one's heart can be attained, and one can be reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land.

One should observe the precepts with a pure and single mind, always thinking of being reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land day and night without interruption for ten days and ten nights. I will have compassion for all of them and cause them to be reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land.
The Buddha said:

In the world, people who aspire to be virtuous and wise, who cultivate goodness and practice the Way while living at home, dwell with their wives in the midst of affection and desire, have many worries and sufferings, and are too busy with family affairs to observe the great fast with a pure and single mind;

Although they are unable to leave home and abandon desires, when they have free time, they should straighten their minds and thoughts, do good deeds with their bodies, and single-mindedly practice the Way for ten days and ten nights.

If one is unable to do so, one should contemplate and examine deeply, wishing to liberate oneself. Below, one should cut off thoughts and remove worries, not thinking about family affairs, and not sharing a bed with a woman.

One should be upright in body and mind, cut off desires, single-mindedly observe the precepts and be pure, and wholeheartedly think of being born in AmitÃ¢bha's land, without interruption for a day and a night. Upon the end of life, they will all go and be born in that land, transformed and born in a lotus flower in a pond of the seven treasures. One can attain wisdom and courage, and dwell in a palace of the seven treasures, freely doing as one wishes.
It is next like the first group above.
The Buddha said to Bodhisattva Ajita:
The innumerable gods, people, bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs of the eight directions and above and below have been born in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land.
The great assembly all gather in the water of the pond of the seven treasures.

They all sat on a large lotus flower, each confessing their moral conduct and good deeds. Each person spoke of the good dharmas they had practiced while seeking the Way in their past lives, the origins of where they came from, what they enjoyed, their knowledge of the scriptures and wisdom, and the merits they had practiced, passing it down from the upper to the lower.

Knowing the scriptures to have clarity and obscurity, wisdom to have depths and shallows, great and small, and virtue to have superiority and inferiority, thickness and thinness, they naturally knew the distinctions.
With talents, wisdom, and bravery, they observed and illuminated each other, with propriety and harmony, all rejoicing.
Their wisdom was courageous and they did not depend on each other.
The Buddha said:
Those people did not previously create merit, but lightly and playfully did good deeds, not believing it to be so.
They were lazy and thought it was acceptable.
When the time came, they all gathered to discuss the scriptures and the Way, but they were naturally pressed for time and their responses were slow.
The wisdom and spiritual attainments of the Way were outstanding and extraordinary, with talents and abilities high and fierce, yet alone on the periphery, weak.
Only then did he regret it, but regret is already out, what benefit will it be later?
But in his heart he was sullen and missed them just like that.
The Buddha said:
The assembly of bodhisattvas and arhats in AmitÃ¢bha Buddha's land naturally gathers together.
Concentrating the mind and controlling the thoughts, straightening the body and practicing correctly, they play and penetrate deeply.
They all follow each other in flying, turning, coming and going, making offerings to the utmost.
With joyful hearts and delight, they all observe the practice of the Way together, practicing harmoniously for a long time.
With fierce talents and wisdom, their aspirations are like empty space, diligently seeking their vows.
The mind will never turn back, the thoughts will never change, and there will never be a time of slacking off.
Although seeking the Way, externally it seems slow, but internally it is uniquely urgent and swift, with a relaxed and empty middle, just obtaining the middle.
The middle represents harmony, naturally dignified and proper.
Collected and upright, body and mind are pure, without love or desire, without attachment or greed, without various faults and impurities.
Their aspirations are all individually stable and beautiful, without increase or decrease.
Seeking the Way is harmonious and correct, without error or deviation.
In accordance with the Way and Dharma, following the sutras and regulations, not daring to violate or stumble.
If in the eight directions, above and below, there are no boundaries, freely doing as one wishes, reaching the endless and boundless, all naturally becoming the Way.
Vast and expansive, thinking of the Way without other thoughts.
Without worries or thoughts, naturally effortless, empty and established, vast and peaceful without desires.
Making good wishes, seeking with all one's heart, full of compassion and pity, with a sincere and proper mind, combining propriety and righteousness.
Penetrating and unobstructed, harmonious and in accord, with praise and admiration inside and out, surpassing liberation;
Able to ascend into nirvana, forever in accord with the brightness of virtue and the Way.
Naturally preserving and protecting each other, the true nourishment of joyful intentions, the true nourishment is pure and clean.
Aspiring for the unsurpassed, the purity of tranquility and stability, the tranquility and bliss that is limitless, the goodness and excellence that is incomparable.
The majestic radiance shines, the shining illuminates and opens up, the natural characteristics in the natural, the existence of the natural root, naturally forming the five lights.
The five lights reach the nine colors, the nine colors revolve and transform, changing hundreds of thousands of times, the naturalness of Uttarakuru, naturally forming the seven treasures.
Horizontally grasping to form myriad things, the essence of light and brightness all emerge, the beauty is extremely wonderful and limitless, that country is extremely like this.
Why not strive to do good?
Contemplate the naturalness of the Way, and attach to the unsurpassed, above and below, penetrating through the boundless, abandoning aspirations in the void.
Why not each strive diligently?
Strive to seek for yourselves, and you can transcend and leave.
Be reborn in AmitÄbha Buddha's land, and cut off the five evil destinies.
Naturally blocked and obstructed, ascending the Way to the ultimate, easy to go without people.
That land is not contrary, naturally following along.
Why not abandon worldly affairs?
Practice and seek morality and virtue, and you can attain extreme longevity, with an endless lifespan.
Why be attached to worldly affairs?
Busily worrying together about impermanence.

The people of the world are shallow and vulgar, all arguing about things that are not urgent, all in this place of intense evil and extreme suffering, diligently working to make a living, using it to support each other, no honor or lowliness, no wealth or poverty, no old or young, no male or female, all should worry about money and possessions together, having or not being the same.
Worrying and thinking are the same, anxious and sorrowful, accumulating thoughts and considerations, being driven by the mind, without any peace.

Those with fields worry about their fields, those with houses worry about their houses, those with oxen worry about their oxen, those with horses worry about their horses, those with livestock worry about their livestock, those with slaves worry about their slaves, those with clothes, bedding, money, property, gold, silver, and treasures also worry about them together.

Thinking deeply and sighing repeatedly, they worry and are anxious, unexpectedly encountering impermanence - being swept away, burned, bound, suddenly attacked, and drowned by water, fire, thieves, enemies, and creditors - the worry and distress in their chests have no end.

They hold grudges in their hearts, harboring anger and resentment, with illnesses in their chests and abdomen, never free from suffering and distress. Their minds are firm and their intentions are resolute, with no room for letting go. Sometimes they collapse and hide, ending their lives and abandoning them, with no one following.
Whether noble or humble, powerful or weak, rich or poor, they have these worries and fears. Suffering like this, they gather various cold and hot feelings and live with pain.

Those from poor families suffer from poverty and hardship, and lack of fields. They worry about wanting to have fields, lack of houses and worry about wanting to have houses, lack of oxen and worry about wanting to have oxen, lack of horses and worry about wanting to have horses, lack of the six domestic animals and worry about wanting to have the six domestic animals, lack of male and female servants and worry about wanting to have male and female servants, lack of clothing, bedding, money, goods, food and drink and worry about wanting to have them.
Having one but lacking one, having this but lacking that, thinking of having them equally.
Having a little but having it all given away, suffering like this, one should seek again.
Thinking does not benefit, and cannot be obtained in time. Body and mind are both exhausted, sitting and standing are uneasy, and worries follow one. The suffering is like this.

The burning heart does not leave anger and resentment alone, and also binds the masses with cold and heat, living together with pain. Sometimes sitting through life, one dies prematurely, and is also unwilling to do good and practice the Way.
When life ends in death, all will go far away alone, heading towards their destinations, and no one can know the ways of good and evil.

Sometimes in this world, fathers, sons, brothers, husbands and wives, family members, and relatives within and outside the family, living between heaven and earth, should respect and love each other, and should not hate each other.
If there is something, they should share it with each other, and should not be greedy or stingy.
Words and expressions should be harmonious, and one should not contradict each other.
If there is a dispute in the mind and anger arises, the resentment in this life is slight and jealousy is hated, but in the next life it becomes more serious and turns into a great resentment.
Why is it so?
It is like the present matter, wanting to harm each other again, although not immediately responding to each other's urgent needs.

However, the sorrow and pain bind the spirit, and naturally the consciousness is engraved and cannot be separated. All will face each other in life and meet each other again, and will repay each other.

When a person is in the world, amidst love and desire, going alone, coming alone, dying alone, being born alone, they must go to a place of suffering and happiness, and the body must endure it alone, with no one to replace them.
Good and evil transform, and misfortune and evil await in advance, one must ascend alone and go far to another place, no one can see where one goes.

Good and evil naturally pursue and follow one's actions, in the dark and obscure, separated for a long time, with different paths, no chance of meeting again, it is very difficult to encounter each other again.
Why not abandon family affairs?
Each should be vigorous and healthy, strive to do good, and diligently seek liberation, one can attain extreme longevity.
Yet they are unwilling to seek the Way, and want to wait for what happiness?

In this way, worldly people do not believe that doing good brings good, do not believe that practicing the Way leads to the Way, do not believe that after death one is reborn in the next world, and do not believe that giving brings blessings and virtues. They simply do not believe in these things.

They think that this is not so, and that there is no such thing. Because of this, they only see what is before their eyes, hear what is passed down from each other, continue in a succession of generations, and inherit the teachings of their fathers.

Their ancestors did not originally do good, did not originally practice the Way, were ignorant in body and spirit, had blocked minds and closed thoughts, did not see the great Way, and had no ability to see where people go after death. No one could know this;
There were simply no witnesses to the Way of good and evil, and no one spoke of whether good and evil deeds bring blessings and virtues,
or whether they lead to misfortune, calamity, and punishment. Everyone competed in doing these things, and there was nothing strange about it.

As for the way of death and rebirth, they continue to transmigrate, sometimes a child crying for a parent, or a parent crying for a child, or a younger sibling crying for an older sibling, or an older sibling crying for a younger sibling, or a wife crying for a husband, or a husband crying for a wife, upside down and chaotic, the root of impermanence, all will pass away and cannot be obtained forever.
Those who are taught and guided to believe in the Way are few, they will all die and be reborn, without rest.
Such people are ignorant and reckless, they do not believe in the scriptures, each wanting to indulge their desires.

Their minds do not contemplate, they are foolish in desire, they do not understand morality and virtue, they are confused by anger, they greedily crave wealth and sex, because of this they do not attain the Way, they will have to undergo hardship again, ending up in a bad place, never able to stop and rest, their pain is very lamentable.

Sometimes within the family, between husband and wife, father and son, brothers, and couples, even to the point of life and death, they cry for each other, think of each other with longing, worry and resentment are intertwined, love binds them, the mind is pained, they look at each other with attachment, bound day and night without release.
They are taught to view morality but their minds are not enlightened, they think of love and desire without separation, blocked and deluded, intertwined and obscured, unable to contemplate.

The mind itself is upright and decisive about worldly matters, but if one focuses solely on practicing the Way, one will quickly reach the end, and when life ends and the life force is exhausted, one cannot attain the Way, and there is nothing to be done.
All are greedy for love and desire, and there are many who do not understand this kind of Dharma, while few attain the Way.

The world is bustling and unreliable. The noble and humble, the powerful and wealthy, the young and old, men and women, each busy with their own affairs, diligently harming themselves, harboring killing intent, with evil qi shrouded in obscurity, all are dispirited.
Acting falsely, doing evil, going against heaven and earth, not following people's hearts.
De and dao are not evil, first following along with them, indulging in what they do, their lifespan not yet reached, suddenly snatching it away.
Falling into the evil realms below, suffering for many generations, turning and turning in sorrow and poison, for many tens of millions of years, with no end in sight.
The pain is indescribable, pitiable indeed.
The Buddha told the Bodhisattvas such as Ajita:
The gods, emperors, and people, I tell you all, the things created in the world, people sit and cannot attain the Way because of this. You should contemplate this thoroughly!
The evil ones should be let go, abandoned and kept far away, and follow the good ones.

You should firmly uphold it and not recklessly do wrong. Increase in doing good, whether great or small, much or little, the glory of desire is all impermanent and cannot be enjoyed. You will be separated from it and there will be nothing enjoyable.
In the time of the Buddha, those who had faith and accepted the Buddha's teachings deeply, and practiced the Way and virtue, were all my younger brothers.
Those who wished to study the Buddha's precepts were all my disciples.
Those who wished to leave home and abandon wife and children, cut off wealth and desires, and become monks and bhiká¹£us for the Buddha, were all my descendants.

My world is very difficult to encounter. Those who wish to be born in AmitÄbha Buddha's land can attain wisdom and courage, and be respected by the masses. Do not follow your desires and violate the scriptures and precepts, falling behind others;
If you have doubts and do not understand the scriptures, ask the Buddha again and he will explain it for you.
Bodhisattva Ajita knelt with his palms joined and said:
The Buddha's majestic spirit is revered, and the sutras he speaks are excellent.
We have listened to the sutras and memorized them all.
The world is truly as the Buddha says, without any difference.
Now the Buddha has compassion for us, revealing the great path and teaching the way of rebirth. Our ears and eyes are enlightened and we will attain liberation forever. If we are reborn again,
we will listen to the Buddha's sutras and no one will not be filled with loving kindness, joy, and understanding.
The gods, emperors, people, and all crawling and flying creatures will receive blessings, and none will not be liberated from worries and suffering.
The Buddha's teachings and precepts are profound and good, with no end or bottom.

The wisdom and knowledge seen by the Buddha encompass the events of the eight directions, above and below, past, present, and future, with no higher or lower, no boundaries or limits. It is extremely difficult to hear the Buddha's teachings.
We have been kind to the Buddha, and those who have attained liberation are all due to the Buddha's diligent study and profound wisdom in seeking the Way in his past lives.
His grace and virtue universally cover, and his meritorious deeds are lofty and his radiance penetrates the boundless void.
He penetrates nirvana, teaches and compiles the scriptures, and subdues and transforms with majestic authority.
He transforms the eight directions and above and below, endlessly and boundlessly. The Buddha is the teacher of the Dharma, revered and supreme among the sages, and none can equal the Buddha.
The Buddha is the teacher of the gods, emperors, and people of the eight directions and above and below, and he causes them to attain the Way according to their wishes, great and small.
Now we have been able to meet the Buddha and hear the name of AmitÄbha Buddha. We are extremely joyful, and none have not attained wisdom and clarity.
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Ajita:
If you say this is so, it should be like this.
If one has a compassionate mind towards the Buddha, one will greatly rejoice and truly contemplate the Buddha;
In the world, it has been a long time since there was a Buddha again.
Now I have become a Buddha in this suffering world. The sutras and teachings I have expounded penetrate deeply, cutting off doubts.
Uphold the mind and practice correctly, eliminate all desires and attachments, and sever the roots of all evil.
Wander freely, with wisdom encompassing all.
The various paths, inside and out, are gathered and held together.
Clearly and distinctly, open up the view of the five paths, and determine the path of birth, death, and nirvana.
The Buddha said:

Since countless eons ago, which cannot be counted again, you have practiced the bodhisattva path, wishing to liberate all gods, humans, and all crawling and flying beings. It has been a very long time.
The number of people who have attained the Way and been liberated by you is countless, and the number who have attained the path of nirvana is also countless.

If you, the people of the eight directions, above and below, the gods, emperors, and people, the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen, from your past lives, since countless eons ago, have been transmigrating through these five realms, dying and being reborn, crying out and weeping for each other, turning to crave and yearn for each other, with worries and sorrows, suffering beyond words,

up to this present life, death and rebirth are endless. Now you have met the Buddha and gathered together, and have heard the sound of AmitÃ¢bha Buddha, which is extremely joyful and good. I rejoice with you.

You should also be disgusted with the pain of birth and death. When born, it is extremely painful, extremely bitter, and extremely intense. Even when growing up, it is painful and intense. When dying, it is also painful, bitter, and intense. It is extremely foul-smelling and impure. There is nothing clean about it.
The Buddha has told you all this. You should also decisively cut off this foul-smelling and shameful place.
You should also be upright in mind and body, and do more good deeds.
From then on, always be upright inside and out, keep the body clean, and wash away the defilements of the mind.
Instruct and restrain each other, with inner and outer in harmony, and be truthful in words and deeds.

If one can save oneself and help each other, pulling out all attachments and desires, with a pure and sincere mind, seeking without turning back, establishing the fundamental path of goodness, although one may be diligent and suffer for one life, it is only a brief moment.

Goodness will protect and keep one away from the suffering and distress of the evil paths, pulling out the roots of all suffering and evil, and cutting off all attachments and desires.
They will live long in AmitÄbha Buddha's land, without any pain or itchiness, without any foul odors, without any suffering, without any lust, anger, or ignorance, and without any worries or sorrows.

If they wish to eat or not eat, they can freely choose, and everything will be naturally provided.

Whatever they wish for in their hearts, they should not doubt or regret. Those who wish to be reborn should not sit idly by their faults, but in the borderlands of AmitÄbha Buddha's realm, they will be exiled to the city of the seven treasures for five hundred years.
The Bodhisattva Ajita said:

We will receive the Buddha's strict and weighty teachings, all of us will diligently and single-mindedly seek and request them, and we will respectfully carry them out without daring to doubt or be negligent.
The Buddha told the Bodhisattvas such as Ajita:
If you are able to control your mind and thoughts in this world and not do evil with the body, this is a great virtue and goodness.
Overall, there is a group that is the most incomparable in the eight directions and above and below.
Why is this so?
In the Buddha-lands of the eight directions and above and below, the gods and people all naturally do good, do not do much evil, and are easy to teach and transform.

Now I have become a Buddha in this world, becoming a Buddha amidst the five evils, five pains, and five burnings is the most severe. I teach the people to let go of the five evils, to remove the five pains, and to remove the five burnings. I subdue their minds and make them uphold the five good deeds, attaining the blessings and virtues of the path to liberation, longevity, and nirvana.
The Buddha said:
What are the five evils?
What are the five pains?
What are the five burnings?
What is it that digests the five evils and allows one to obtain the five wholesome deeds?
What is it that upholds the five wholesome deeds and obtains the blessings, longevity, and path to liberation and nirvana?
The Buddha said:
The first evil is:

From the gods and people down to the birds and beasts, insects and worms, they want to do many evils, the strong oppress the weak and turn against each other, killing and injuring each other, devouring each other.

They do not know how to do good, commit evil and go against the way, receive their punishments, the way is natural, they will go and head towards the divine records, violate it without stopping and continue to follow each other;
Therefore there are the poor, the lowly, the beggars, the orphans, the deaf, the blind, the mute, the foolish, the vicious, and those who are weak and insane.
Therefore, there are those who are noble, humble, wealthy, talented, intelligent, wise, and brave, all due to their past lives, when they did good, were kind, filial, and generous.

Therefore, there are official matters, royal laws, prisons, and those who are unwilling to fear and be cautious, do evil, enter the law, receive their faults, heavy punishments, and severe consequences, seeking to be liberated but finding it difficult to escape.

In this world, there are these present before our eyes. After the end of life, there are places to enter the dark and receive a body to be reborn, just like the severe suffering and extreme punishments of royal law.

Therefore, there are naturally hells, animals, hungry ghosts, insects, flying creatures, and wriggling creatures. They transform their bodies, change their evil ways, and their lifespans, souls, spirits, essences, and consciousnesses naturally enter their destinies, receive forms, and rely on wombs.
They will alone encounter and follow each other to be born together, and they will turn to repay each other and restore each other.
Evil consequences and punishments, with many matters not yet exhausted, they will never be able to escape.
Transmigrating within this, for countless eons there is no chance of escape, and it is difficult to attain liberation, with pain that cannot be described.
Naturally, there is this between heaven and earth. Although it is not immediate or violent, it accords with the time, but it takes the way of nature, and all good and evil return to it.
This is a great evil, a great pain, a great burning.
The suffering is like this, with sorrow and lamentation, comparable to a great fire burning a person's body.

If a person can, within this, single-mindedly control their thoughts, rectify their body, and practice correctly, doing only good and not many evils, then their body alone will be liberated and attain blessings and virtues. They can attain long life, transcend the world, and attain the way of nirvana in the heavens, which is a great good.

The second evil is:

The emperors, officials, and people of the world, fathers and sons, brothers, family members, and couples have little righteousness and do not follow proper orders. They are extravagant, licentious, arrogant and self-important, each wanting to indulge their desires and be unrestrained. They deceive each other and are not afraid of death.

Their minds and words are different, their speech and thoughts are not real, they are deceitful and not loyal, flattering and skillful in speech, their actions are not upright, they envy each other, slander each other, and frame others unjustly;

The ruler is not clear-minded and does not investigate thoroughly, and employs ministers below him. The ministers below him are in power and can carry out their plans. They know that their actions are not upright and are manipulated by them, falsely harming the loyal, good, and virtuous, not in accord with the will of heaven and greatly violating reason.

Ministers deceive their ruler, sons deceive their father, younger brothers deceive their elder brothers, wives deceive their husbands, family members and relatives inside and outside sue each other, each harboring greed and lust, their minds are poisoned with anger, and they are deluded, ignorant, and foolish, wanting to increase their desires.
There is no distinction of high and low, male and female, old and young, and everyone's mind is the same in wanting to enrich themselves.
They destroy their families and lose their lives without any regard for the past or future, and their families and relatives are brought down with them.
Sometimes even the knowledge and friends within and outside the family, the foolish people in the villages and markets, and the wild people, continue to engage with them and mutually harm each other.
They argue over wealth, fight and quarrel, become angry enemies, and continue to argue over winning and losing. The stingy and rich burn with anxiety and are unwilling to give.
They guard and cherish their possessions with spells, sitting and thinking about them, their minds troubled and their bodies suffering.
In the end, they have nothing to rely on. They come alone and leave alone, with no one following them.

The blessings and virtues of good and evil, the calamities and punishments that follow one's life, whether one is born in a place of joy or enters into painful poison, one will then regret it, but what can be done about it?

Sometimes worldly people with foolish minds and little wisdom, seeing goodness, slander it and are averse to emulating it. They only want to engage in falsehood and do what is improper, only want to steal, always harboring a poisonous mind, wanting to obtain others' wealth to use for their own support, dissipating and exhausting it and seeking more.
With an aberrant and abnormal mind, they are always alone, fearful, and afraid of others having opinions. At the time, they do not consider things, and only regret when it is too late.
In this world, they are imprisoned by the long-serving officials, naturally heading towards and receiving their misfortune.

In the world, there are the poor, beggars, and the orphaned and alone, who are only sitting in their previous lives, not believing in morality and virtue, unwilling to do good, and doing evil in this world. The celestial beings separately record them, and upon the end of their lives, they enter the evil paths.

Therefore, there are naturally the hells, animals, hungry ghosts, and the class of wriggling insects, turning and turning within them, for life after life, for countless eons, without a chance of escape, difficult to attain liberation, with pain indescribable.
These are the two great evils, the two pains, and the two burnings.
The suffering is like this, comparable to a fire that is more intense than burning the human body.

If a person can, within this, single-mindedly control their thoughts, be upright in body and correct in conduct, and solely do good without doing many evils, then their body alone will be liberated and they will obtain blessings and virtues. They can attain long life, transcend the world, and attain the path to nirvana in the heavens. These are the two great goods.
The Buddha said:
The three evils are as follows:
All the people in the world are born in dependence on each other, living together in the space between heaven and earth. The lifespan in this place cannot last for many years.

There are wealthy and noble elders who are wise and virtuous, and below there are poor and lowly weak and foolish ones. Among them, there are those who are not good, only thinking of evil and having an impure body and mind, always thinking of licentiousness and being filled with thoughts in the chest, with desires intertwined, sitting and standing uncomfortably;
With greedy thoughts and stinginess, they want to obtain things unjustly. They glance at beautiful women with evil intentions and licentiousness.
They are disgusted with their wives and secretly go out. They use the family's possessions to give to others and do wrong.
They gather for food and drink and exclusively do evil together. They raise troops, become thieves, attack cities, fight, rob, kill, cut off, and forcefully take what is not theirs.
They take people's wealth and goods, steal and obtain them, and are unwilling to engage in business. They are unwilling to do what they should seek.
With evil intentions outside, they are unable to focus on their work. They want to bind things together and forcefully coerce them, taking them back to support their families and living together.
Giving free rein to their minds and indulging their desires, they engage in extreme pleasure and disrupt the wives of others.
They may not avoid the elders in their own relatives, and the crowd despises them. The family members inside and outside are troubled and angry with them.
They also do not fear the laws of the county government, and there is nothing they avoid or record.

Such evil naturally becomes a prison. The sun and moon illuminate, the spirit of consciousness clearly records, and the various spirits capture and record. Therefore, there are naturally hells, animals, hungry ghosts, insects, flying creatures, and wriggling creatures. They revolve within these realms, generation after generation, for countless eons, without any hope of escape, difficult to attain liberation, and the pain is indescribable.
These are the three great evils, the three pains, and the three burnings.
The suffering is like this, as if a fire arises and burns a person's body.

If a person can, within this, single-mindedly control their thoughts, rectify their body, and practice correctly, only doing good and not doing many evils, then their body alone will be liberated and they will attain blessings and virtues. They can attain long life, transcend the world, and attain the path of nirvana in the heavens. This is the three great goods.
The Buddha said:
The four evils are:
The people are unable to do good, they destroy each other, and they take turns instructing each other to do many evils together.
The master only wants to spread slander, speak harshly, scold, lie, be jealous, fight and create chaos, hate good people, and destroy the virtuous. He takes pleasure in the side.
He is also unfilial and does not support his parents, disregards teachers, friends, and acquaintances, is untrustworthy and difficult to be sincere.
He considers himself great, noble, and has the Way, acts recklessly with power and force, oppresses others, and cannot know himself.
He does evil and is not ashamed, considers himself tough, and wants others to serve and fear him.
He also does not fear Heaven, Earth, the spirits, the sun, or the moon, cannot be taught to do good, cannot be transformed, and acts arrogantly as he pleases.
He also has no thoughts of worry or sorrow, and does not know the meaning of fear.
His arrogance is like this, and the celestial spirits record it.
Relying on his past life, he has made some blessings and virtues, and small goodness supports and protects him.
In this world, if one commits evil, it will all be exhausted, and all good will be lost day by day, and evil will pursue one.

The body stands alone and empty, with nothing to rely on, receiving heavy misfortune and retribution, with a lifespan surrounded by all kinds of evil, naturally rushing towards it, and being chased without rest, naturally surrounded by all kinds of evil, exhausted and lacking.

Having a name and record in the divine realm, misfortune and blame will lead one to meet and obtain it, naturally heading towards receiving excessive punishment, with body and mind shattered, the spirit and form suffering to the extreme, unable to escape, only able to move forward and enter the fiery cauldron.
At that time, what use is it to regret? What can be done?

The heavenly way is natural and cannot be transgressed, so there are naturally hells, animals, hungry ghosts, insects, flying creatures, and wriggling creatures, revolving among them, generation after generation, for countless eons, without a chance of escape, difficult to attain liberation, with pain beyond words.
These are the four great evils, the four pains, the four burnings.
The suffering is like this, comparable to a fire burning a person's body.

If a person can, within this, single-mindedly control their thoughts, be upright in body and correct in conduct, do only good and not many evils, then they can alone attain liberation and obtain blessings and virtues, and can attain long life, transcend the world, and attain the way of nirvana.
These are the four great goods.
The Buddha said:
As for the five evils:

The people of the world are lazy and indolent, unwilling to do good or think about making a living. Their wives and children are hungry and cold, and their parents are the same. They want to admonish their children, but the children have evil thoughts and respond with angry eyes, disobeying and going against them, more rebellious than wild people, comparable to enemies, not as good as having no children.
They falsely borrow from everyone, causing everyone to hate them, and have no thought of repaying their debts.

They are poor and destitute, unable to obtain anything, and they argue and quarrel, indulging in play and wandering aimlessly. They are accustomed to obtaining things for free and using them to support themselves, without fear of prohibitions. They eat and drink excessively, drinking alcohol and enjoying delicacies, coming and going without any sense of propriety, rude and impetuous, not understanding human feelings, and forcefully imposing themselves.
Seeing others happy, they hate and resent them. They have no righteousness or propriety, using their own ideas, and cannot be advised or enlightened.

They also do not worry about their parents, wives, or children, whether they have anything or not. They do not think of repaying their parents' kindness, nor do they think of the kindness and goodness of their teachers.
Their minds always think of evil, their mouths always speak evil, and their bodies always do evil.

They do not accomplish anything, do not believe in morality and virtue, do not believe in the existence of sages and wise ones of the past, do not believe that doing good deeds is the way to attain liberation from the world, and do not believe that there are Buddhas in the world.
They want to kill arhats, cause schism in the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha, always want to kill people, want to kill their father, mother, elder and younger brothers, wife and children, relatives and friends.
Their parents, brothers, wife and children, relatives and friends, hate them and want them to die when they see them.
They do not believe the words of the Buddha's scriptures, do not believe that human life ends and after death one is reborn in the next world.
They do not believe that doing good brings good, and do not believe that doing evil brings evil.
Such men and women, their minds and thoughts are all like this, going against and rebelling, ignorant and confused, angry and lustful, knowing nothing, thinking their own way is good and very wise.

They do not know where they come from, where they will be reborn, or where they will go in the future. They are unwilling to be kind and filial, and are evil and rebellious towards Heaven and Earth. In the meantime, they hope for good fortune, wanting to attain eternal life and immortality, but will eventually return to the path of birth, death, suffering, and the consequences of good and evil. The evil they have done will lead to various misfortunes and they will not be able to attain liberation.
They cannot be transformed to do good, and even if taught with kind words and guided about the suffering of death, and the consequences of good and evil, they still do not believe it.
Even though they are taught with a compassionate heart, wanting to liberate them, it does not benefit them.
Their minds are closed and their thoughts are not enlightened. When their life is about to end, they all regret it, but what can they do after that?
If they had not planned to do good in advance, what benefit would it be at the last moment?

Between Heaven and Earth, the five paths are each clear. Vast, deep, and vast, they pass on to each other the consequences of good and evil, and the body must bear them alone, with no one to replace them.
The Way is natural, following one's actions, pursuing life and birth, unable to be abandoned. Good people do good, compassionate and filial, from pleasure to pleasure, from light to light.
Evil people do evil, from suffering to suffering, from darkness to darkness.
Who can know this?
Only the Buddha sees and knows.
Teaching and instructing the people, few believe and use it. Birth and death do not cease, and the evil paths are endless.

Thus, the people of the world cannot be fully described, and so there are naturally hells, animals, hungry ghosts, insects, flying and crawling creatures, and so on, transmigrating among them, accumulating kalpas for generations without a chance of escape, difficult to attain liberation, and the pain is indescribable.
These are the five great evils, five pains, and five burnings.
The suffering is like this, comparable to a fire burning a person's body.

If a person can, within this, single-mindedly control their thoughts, rectify their body and conduct, and make their words and actions consistent, acting with utmost sincerity, speaking as they say and not wavering in their mind or words, creating only good and not many evils, then they can alone attain liberation and obtain blessings and virtues, and can attain long life, transcend the world, and attain the path to nirvana.
These are the five great wholesome acts.
The Buddha told the bodhisattvas such as Ajita:

I have told you all that the five evils and suffering in this world are like this, causing the five pains to arise, causing the five burnings to arise, and causing them to arise and perpetuate each other.
The people in the world are unwilling to do good and want to create many evils. Those who dare to commit these evil acts will all naturally have to go through and enter the evil paths.

Or in this world, they first suffer from illness, and after death, they are unable to be reborn. Showing this to the multitude, when their lives end, they enter into extreme great suffering, sorrow, and grief, burning themselves with their own thoughts, and turning to burn each other, until finally they become enemies and harm each other. Starting from small beginnings, it grows to great difficulty and hardship, all from greed, lust, and desire for wealth and beauty, unwilling to be patient and generous, each wanting to indulge themselves, without any more right or wrong, wanting to gain a reputation for strength.
Pushed by foolish desires, unable to obtain what they think in their hearts, they become angry and frustrated in their chests.
Bound by wealth and beauty, without liberation, they do not know when to be content, being thick-skinned and arguing over desires, without any reflection.
In wealth, nobility, and glory, at that time being patient and not knowing to give generously, their power is brief, and they follow evil reputations and burn.
Sitting in hardship, after a long time it becomes extremely difficult, naturally following without any end.

The royal laws are spread far and wide, naturally exposing and connecting the upper and lower levels, with a net of regulations and records, tightly and securely. Those who enter this will be in it, as it has been since ancient times. Alas, it is to be pitied.
There is no meaning or principle at all, and they do not know the right path.

The path to liberation from the world, non-action, and nirvana is joyful, good, and supremely blissful.

They should worry about the path to liberation from the world, they should worry about cutting off birth and death, and pulling out the root of evil, they should worry about cutting off the path of evil suffering in the hells, animal realm, hungry ghost realm, and all crawling and flying beings.

When doing something, you should first think it through carefully.

If you are sincere and faithful, you will attain the Way and leave behind all. The Buddha said:

If you increase your practice of various good deeds, spread kindness and virtue, refrain from violating the precepts, endure, make energetic progress, concentrate your mind, and cultivate wisdom, and teach each other to create good and virtue,

They all respectfully follow the teachings and guidance, and immediately the ruler leads the transformation into goodness, instructing his subordinates, fathers their sons, elder brothers their younger brothers, husbands their wives, and the family members and relatives inside and outside the house mutually instruct each other, doing good and following the path, upholding the sutras and precepts, each being upright and restrained, with no distinction of high or low, male or female, all joyfully and purely observing the precepts, harmonious and in accord with principles, happily and lovingly filial, mutually restraining each other.

Those who obtain the Buddha's sutras all uphold and contemplate them, not committing what should not be done, immediately repenting past evils and turning to goodness, abandoning evil and taking up the correct, hearing in the morning and changing in the evening, upholding the sutras and precepts more diligently than a fool who obtains a treasure.

Wherever the Buddha went in the various countries, he bestowed the sutras and precepts. The ministers were filial to the ruler and loyal and honest in receiving orders, not daring to disobey.
The father spoke to the son with filial obedience and acceptance, and brothers, husbands and wives, relatives and friends, superiors and inferiors, spoke to each other with harmony and reason.
The noble and humble, the young and old, respectfully served each other, with propriety and righteousness, not contradicting each other.

None of them did not change their past and cultivate the future, wash their hearts and change their conduct, be upright in the middle and outside, naturally do good, and immediately obtain what they wished for.
All of them followed the way of natural transformation.
If one wishes for immortality, one can obtain longevity;
If one wishes to transcend the world, one can obtain the path to nirvana.
The Buddha said:
The Buddha's majestic spiritual power and weighty virtue, eliminating evil and transforming goodness, none are not liberated.
Now I have appeared in the world, in this evil, suffering world, I have become a Buddha, with compassion and pity, teaching and guiding.
The gods, emperors, ministers, officials, local officials, and people, according to their wishes and preferences, are all made to attain the Way.

Wherever the Buddha goes, through the prefectures, countries, counties, cities, villages, and markets, there is no place that is not prosperous and abundant. The world is at peace, the sun and moon shine twice as bright, the wind and rain come at the right time, and the people are at ease.
The strong do not oppress the weak, each gets what they deserve, there are no bad years or epidemics, no one is sick or weak.
Weapons do not rise up, the country has no thieves or bandits, there is no injustice, no one is imprisoned.
The ruler, ministers, and people all rejoice, being loyal, kind, and sincere, each abiding by their own principles, all guarding their own countries, harmonious and filial, all joyful.
The rich and poor share kindness and bestow virtue, their hearts joyful and happy, all respecting and loving each other, yielding with righteousness and humility.
They serve each other with courtesy, like father and son, like elder and younger brother, all being benevolent and virtuous.
Harmonious and orderly, without any disputes, their goodness is boundless.
The Buddha said:

I pity you all, my children, and wish to deliver you, even more than parents love their children. Now, the gods in the eight directions, above and below, emperors, people, and all crawling and flying creatures, who have obtained the Buddha's sutras and precepts and uphold the Buddha's Way, all attain wisdom and their minds are fully enlightened, and none do not transcend and attain liberation from worries and suffering.
Now I have become a Buddha, and am in the midst of the five evils, five pains, and five burnings, subduing the five evils, extinguishing the five pains, and eradicating the five burnings.

Using goodness to conquer evil, I pull out the poisonous suffering, enabling them to attain the five paths, enabling them to attain the five kinds of goodness and brightness, burning away evil so that it does not arise.

After my nirvana, the sutra teachings will gradually be cut off, and people will become deceitful, gradually engaging in many evils again, no longer doing good, and the five burnings will arise again, the five pains and severe suffering will return to the previous state, naturally reverting, and after a long time, it will become even more severe, indescribable.
I am only speaking for you lesser practitioners.
The Buddha told the bodhisattvas such as Ajita:
You should each contemplate and uphold it, and teach it to each other, not daring to violate the Buddha's sutra teachings.
The bodhisattva Ajita knelt and joined his palms, saying:
The Buddha's teachings on the path are extremely painful.
The evils committed by worldly people are so severe.
The Buddha has compassion for all and delivers them all. They all say they accept the Buddha's weighty teachings. They request to teach each other, not daring to violate them.
